title: 107_s2710
content: The Act titled "Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002" provides a credit for small business employee health insurance expenses under SEC. 45G of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002 offers a credit for small business employee health insurance expenses under section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code. The credit is based on the amount paid by the taxpayer during the taxable year for qualified employee health insurance expenses, with the applicable percentage determined based on the average annual rate of wages of qualified employees. The Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002 provides a tax credit for small businesses based on the average annual rate of wages of qualified employees. If the average annual rate of wages exceeds $10,000, the credit is 50 percent for employers with not more than 10 employees, and for employers with more than 10 employees, the credit is based on the excess amount. The tax credit for small businesses under the Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002 is based on the average annual rate of wages of qualified employees. For employers with more than 10 employees, the credit calculation varies depending on whether the average annual rate of wages exceeds or does not exceed $10,000. The tax credit calculation for small businesses with more than 10 qualified employees is based on the average annual rate of wages. If the average annual rate of wages exceeds $10,000, the calculation involves subtracting a percentage determined under paragraph (3) from a percentage determined by the number of qualified employees and the amount by which the rate of wages exceeds $10,000. The tax credit calculation for small businesses with more than 10 qualified employees is based on the average annual rate of wages. If the rate exceeds $10,000, a percentage is subtracted based on the number of employees and the wage amount. The applicable percentage is zero if determined under paragraph (2), (3), or (4) is less than zero. For employers with not more than 50 qualified employees and an average annual wage not exceeding $30,000, the applicable percentage is at least 5 percent. The dollar limitation per employee for qualified employee health benefits is also specified. The tax credit calculation for small businesses is based on the average annual rate of wages. If wages do not exceed $30,000, the applicable percentage is at least 5 percent. The dollar limitation per employee for qualified employee health benefits is $2,000 for self-only coverage and $5,000 for family coverage. The tax credit for small businesses is based on average annual wages. The dollar limit for employee health benefits is $2,000 for self-only coverage and $5,000 for family coverage. An employer is considered as described in subsection (b) if they employed the required number of employees on business days in the preceding years. An employer is considered as described in subsection (b) if they employed the required number of employees on business days in the preceding years, with specific conditions for employers not in existence in the preceding year. The determination of an employer's employee health insurance expenses is based on the average number of employees expected to be employed in the current year. Qualified expenses refer to amounts paid for health insurance coverage for at least 50% of qualified employees, with an exception for amounts paid under salary reduction arrangements. The term 'qualified employee' refers to any employee who typically works more than 30 hours. Health insurance coverage expenses for employers are based on providing coverage to at least 50% of qualified employees, with an exception for amounts paid under salary reduction arrangements. The term 'qualified employee' means an employee who works more than 30 hours per week, excluding those eligible for subsidized health plans, entitled to benefits under Medicare, or participants in certain programs. The term 'qualified employee' refers to an employee working over 30 hours per week, not eligible for subsidized health plans, entitled to Medicare benefits, or participating in specific programs. The employee must also meet certain criteria outlined in section 162(l)(2) related to benefits under various titles of the Social Security Act and other medical care programs. The term 'employee' excludes certain individuals but includes leased employees as defined in section 414(n). 'Wages' are defined as per section 3121(a). The meaning of section 401(c)(1) includes leased employees as defined in section 414(n). 'Wages' are defined as per section 3121(a). Rules similar to section 52 apply. No double benefit allowed for qualified employee health insurance expenses. Section 38(b) is amended for the general business credit. The amendment to section 38(b) of the Internal Revenue Code allows for the employee health insurance expenses credit under section 45G to be part of the general business credit. No carrybacks of the section 45G credit are permitted before the effective date. No portion of the unused business credit attributable to the employee health insurance expenses credit under section 45G can be carried back before January 1, 2003. The amendments made by this section apply to small business employee health insurance expenses incurred after the enactment of this Act, starting from taxable years after December 31, 2002.
